channel.title: How to answer a question in a helpful way
channel.description:
Didn't know where to post this! Figured I would post it in programming general. This goes for other forum-questions aswell ;)
It's my impression that many answers to questions as of late have sounded a bit... well... [i]retarded[/i] (for lack of a better word). While there might be a few folks out there genuinely in need of a good roasting, most people just want some help. There's no need to make it more painful than it already may be.
Here are some excellent suggestions from ESR's oft-quoted essay, [URL=http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html#id266392]How To Ask Questions The Smart Way[/URL]:
[URL=http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html#id266392][b]How To Answer Questions in a Helpful Way[/b][/URL]
[b]Be gentle.[/b] Problem-related stress can make people seem rude or stupid even when they're not.
[b]Reply to a first offender off-line.[/b] There is no need of public humiliation for someone who may have made an honest mistake. A real newbie may not know how to search archives or where the FAQ is stored or posted.
[b]If you don't know for sure, say so![/b] A wrong but authoritative-sounding answer is worse than none at all. Don't point anyone down a wrong path simply because it's fun to sound like an expert. Be humble and honest; set a good example for both the querent and your peers.
[b]If you can't help, don't hinder.[/b] Don't make jokes about procedures that could trash the user's setup — the poor sap might interpret these as instructions.
[b]Ask probing questions to elicit more details.[/b] If you're good at this, the querent will learn something — and so might you. Try to turn the bad question into a good one; remember we were all newbies once.
While just muttering RTFM is sometimes justified when replying to someone who is just a lazy slob, a pointer to documentation (even if it's just a suggestion to google for a key phrase) is better.
[b]If you're going to answer the question at all, give good value.[/b] Don't suggest kludgy workarounds when somebody is using the wrong tool or approach. Suggest good tools. Reframe the question.
[b]Help your community learn from the question.[/b] When you field a good question, ask yourself “How would the relevant documentation or FAQ have to change so that nobody has to answer this again?” Then send a patch to the document maintainer.
If you did research to answer the question, [b]demonstrate your skills rather than writing as though you pulled the answer out of your ass.[/b] Answering one good question is like feeding a hungry person one meal, but teaching them research skills by example is teaching them to grow food for a lifetime.
Thanks! Hopefully this will eliminate some of the retardation going around the place.
